anchor.surface_text: the Privy Council gave him special leave to appeal, limited to the question whether the prosecution was bad for want of sanction under section 197 of the Criminal Procedure Code. By a further order dated 5th August, 1948, the Privy Council enlarged the scope of the appeal by permitting the appellant to raise the contention that there had been a contravention of section 257 of the Criminal Procedure Code.

anchor.surface_text: W. Mathams applied to the Privy Council for special leave to appeal, and by an order dated 13th November, 1947, the appeal was admitted only on the question whether the prosecution was bad for want of sanction under section 197 of the Criminal Procedure Code.

anchor.surface_text: The learned Judges who heard the appeal on remand held by their judgment, dated 6th September, 1951, that on the evidence both the charges of conspiracy and bribery had been established, and convicted the appellants

arguments.claim: there was contravention of section 257 of the Criminal Procedure Code and a denial of fair trial

holdings.text: The question whether sanction under section 197 was necessary for instituting proceedings against the appellant on charges of conspiracy and of bribery, is concluded by the decisions of the Judicial Committee in H. H. B. Gill v. The King and Phanindra Chandra Neogy v. The King, and must be answered in the negative.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Issue concluded by binding precedent of Judicial Committee in H.H.B. Gill v. The King and Phanindra Chandra Neogy v. The King.

holdings.text: The question whether there was contravention of section 257 of the Criminal Procedure Code and a denial of fair trial must, for the reasons already given, be answered in the affirmative, and the conviction of the appellant set aside on that ground.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Affirmative answer based on prior analysis of procedural irregularity under section 257 CrPC denying fair trial.

holdings.text: By reason of the order of the High Court dated 2nd August 1948 adjourning the hearing and subsequent delays, the appellants did not get reasonable opportunity to examine witnesses on remand, resulting in no fair trial and convictions cannot stand.
holdings.reasoning_summary: High Court delay post-remand led to untraceable witnesses due to war end, partition, migration; no fault of appellants; deprived of rebutting prosecution case with material evidence.

holdings.text: The requirements of section 257 of the Criminal Procedure Code had not been complied with originally by the Tribunal, affirmed by Federal Court, and no effective compliance on remand, vitiating the trial.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Section 257 imperative; summons not properly issued/served; process refused without valid reasons; no opportunity on remand due to delay.

holdings.text: It is essential that rules of procedure designed to ensure justice should be scrupulously followed, and courts should be jealous in seeing that there is no breach of them.
holdings.reasoning_summary: General principle justifying setting aside convictions despite strong prosecution case, to uphold procedural justice.
